title: 111_s563
content: The Act may be cited as the "Utah Recreational Land Exchange Act of 2009". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Utah Recreational Land Exchange Act of 2009," defines key terms related to Federal land in Grand, San Juan, and Uintah Counties, Utah, including maps such as the Grand County Map and the Uintah County Map. The "Utah Recreational Land Exchange Act of 2009" defines terms related to Federal land in Grand, San Juan, and Uintah Counties, Utah, including the Uintah County Map which identifies non-Federal land proposed for transfer to BLM. The curr_chunk dated November 13, 2008, pertains to the exchange of Federal land and non-Federal land in Uintah County, Utah. SEC. 3. EXCHANGE OF LAND. The Secretary must accept the State's offer to convey non-Federal land and reciprocate by conveying Federal land. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights, specific laws, and additional terms agreed upon by the Secretary and the State. Title approval is required for both Federal and non-Federal land. Title approval for the Federal and non-Federal land to be exchanged must be in an acceptable format. Appraisals to determine the value of the land will be conducted by independent appraisers selected jointly by the Secretary and the State, in accordance with applicable law. The appraisals must be submitted for approval before the exchange can proceed. When exchanging Federal land with minerals, the parcel's value is reduced by the percentage of Federal revenue sharing with a State. This adjustment is not considered a property right of the State. Final appraisals for land exchanges must be available for public review at the Utah State Office of the Bureau of Land Management. The Secretary or the State must publish a notice in a newspaper in Salt Lake County, Utah, announcing that appraisals for land exchanges are available for public review. Parcels of Federal and non-Federal land can be exchanged in 3 phases once the appraised values are approved. The 3 phases of land exchange involve phase 1, phase 2, and phase 3, with any remaining non-Federal land categorized accordingly on specific county maps. If agreement is not reached on a parcel exchange, it may be set aside by the Secretary and the State. The Secretary may set aside a parcel to facilitate land exchange. Congress intends the first phase of land exchange to be completed within 360 days of the State offering non-Federal land. The Secretary must reserve an interest in oil shale resources on Federal land. The State must pay the United States a percentage of bonus bids, royalties, and other payments received for oil shale development. Payments are to be made quarterly, and the State is not obligated to develop oil shale resources where the US retains an interest. Federal land reserved by the Secretary for an interest shall be appraised without considering oil shale presence and in accordance with subsection (d). The Federal land is withdrawn from disposition under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws until it is removed from the exchange or conveyed under this Act. The Act addresses the operation of mineral leasing laws, the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970, and the Materials Act of 1947. Any conveyance of land under the Act includes water rights. Land exchanges must be of equal value or equalized. The Act addresses land exchanges of federal and non-federal land, ensuring equal value through adjustments in acreage or addition of state land. The Act addresses land exchanges of federal and non-federal land, ensuring equal value through adjustments in acreage or addition of state land. The Secretary and the State must publish a notice in a newspaper and provide a revised exchange map for public inspection if land is added or removed from the exchange. Copies of the revised exchange must be sent to the relevant committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Secretary and the State must not modify the land exchange until 30 days after publishing a notice and transmitting the revised map to relevant committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 4. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND AFTER EXCHANGE. The non-Federal land acquired by the United States under this Act shall become part of the Federal administrative unit or area in which the land is located, managed in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Mineral leasing laws will not apply to the acquired land until 2 years after the enactment of this Act or the Record of Decision date, subject to valid existing rights. The non-Federal land acquired under this Act becomes part of the Federal administrative unit, managed according to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Mineral leasing laws do not apply until 2 years after enactment or the Record of Decision date, with exceptions for Withdrawal Parcels. Mineral receipts from the acquired non-Federal land are paid into the Treasury's general fund. Federal land acquired under this Act is exempt from section 35 of the Mineral Leasing Act. Grazing permits for domestic livestock on conveyed land must be allowed to continue until the end of the lease term, with adherence to existing terms and conditions. Renewal of grazing leases is permitted under Federal or State law. The holder of a lease, permit, or contract has a preference right to renew it. The Secretary or State can cancel or modify a grazing permit if the land is sold for non-grazing purposes, with limitations for mineral development. (c) Hazardous Materials.-- The Secretary and the State must provide records for review and inspection of hazardous materials on exchanged land. Costs for remedial actions on acquired land are to be covered. The conveyance of Federal land in sec. 33, T. 4 S., R. 24 E., and sec. 4, T. 5 S., R. 24 E., of the Salt Lake Meridian, shall be subject to a 1,000 foot wide scenic easement and a 200 foot wide road right-of-way previously granted to the National Park Service for the Dinosaur National Monument. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for this Act will be appropriated.
